todos.title: Vesting
todos.body: Typical stock options will vest over four years.  Make sure you can purchase unvested stock at financing price if you leave the company or are terminated.

todos.title: Stages
todos.body: Seed funding, Series A'B'C', Qualified IPO.

todos.title: Approval by investor's partnership
todos.body: Secret code that the deal has not been fully approved.

todos.title: Anti-dilution Clause
todos.body: Protects investor if future financing wounds have a lower valuation.

todos.title: Employee Pool Trap
todos.body: larger employee stock option pools are good but they lower your pre-money valuation.  In other words they reduce your valuation.

todos.title: Demo
todos.body: Is the best presentation.

todos.title: Lawyer
todos.body: Is a reflection upon you.  Early stage fees should cost $5,000 to $15,000 and later stages $25,000 to $40,000.

todos.title: Super Angels/Micro VC
todos.body: Individual invested in many startups.

todos.title: Single Vote
todos.body: If you have multiple classes of shares make sure there is only one layer of voting.

todos.title: Clawback
todos.body: If VCs get paid on a good investment but then lose money on a bad investment, the fund might have the option to get back some of the profit paid to the VC.

todos.title: Drag Along Agreement
todos.body: If a certain amount of investors vote one way, the other investors are required to do the same.

todos.title: VC Money Sources
todos.body: Gov't and corporate pension funds, large corporations, banks, institutional investors, educational endowments, high-net-worth individuals, funds of funds, charitable organizations, insurance companies, trusts.  VCs keep little cash on hand and have to ask for capital calls for each investment.  Management fee is usually 1.5 to 2.5%.

todos.title: EIR
todos.body: Entrepreneurs in residence.  Split time working at VC and working on product.

todos.title: Convertible Note Upon Sale of Company
todos.body: Either lender gets money plus interest, lender gets money, interest, and multiple, or a conversion occurs.

todos.title: Two Things VCs Care About
todos.body: Economics and Control.

todos.title: VC Etiquette
todos.body: Don't spam, no means no, don't ask for a referral if you get a no, don't be solo founder,

todos.title: Syndicate
todos.body: Collection of investors. The lead investor should speak for the whole syndicate.

todos.title: 83(b) Election
todos.body: Capital gains treatment.  Must be done within 30 days after receiving your stock in a company.

todos.title: Term Sheet
todos.body: Average 8 pages.

todos.title: Single-trigger acceleration
todos.body: Automatic vesting upon merger of the company.

todos.title: Double trigger acceleration
todos.body: Automatic vesting upon both merger and employee being fired.

todos.title: BATNA
todos.body: Always have in your pocket a best alternative negotiated agreement.  Time things so that you are receiving term sheets at the same time.   Be open and transparent but never share term sheets.

todos.title: Three Keys to Negotiating Financing
todos.body: Achieve a good and fair result, don't kill your relationship or reputation, and understand the deal you are striking.  Pick a few things that really matter to you and let the rest be flexible.  Ask them what their three most important things are.  Get to know whom you are dealing with.  Figure out your superpower and their kryptonite.

todos.title: Four Responses
todos.body: Willing to take lead investment, willing to follow a lead investment, slow no, and hell no.  The middle two are the most dangerous.

todos.title: Less is more
todos.body: When presenting to an investor keep it to 10 slides or less.

todos.title: Protective Provisions
todos.body: Veto rights by investors for certain actions by company.  Ex change stock terms, authorize more stock, issue senior stock, by back common stock, sell company, change incorporation or bylaws, change size of board, pay dividend, borrow money.

todos.title: Experience
todos.body: VCs look at experience of team as much as quality of product.

todos.title: Pattern Recognition
todos.body: VCs are in the business of pattern recognition.  Know the companies that they see as successful and pattern like them.

todos.title: Letter of Intent
todos.body: Used for purchase-sales.

todos.title: Social Media
todos.body: Use it to research your VC.

todos.title: Age of Fund
todos.body: The older the age of the fund, the more problems can occur with investor liquidity.  Most VCs can raise new money when around 70% of existing fund is committed.

todos.title: 409A Valuations
todos.body: Stock options to employees must be fair market value.

todos.title: Financials
todos.body: Should include revenue forecasts and burn rates.

todos.title: Managing Directors/General Partners
todos.body: Run the show. Insist on developing a direct relationship with them.

todos.title: Pro-rata right
todos.body: Right of first refusal.

todos.title: Key Man Clause
todos.body: Provision if a key person leaves the company.

todos.title: Pre v. Post Money Trap
todos.body: Pre-money means they are calculating their equity with their investment added to your valuation (ex $5 with $20 valuation gets 20%).  Post money which is most often used means they are calculating their percent equity without their money added to valuation (ex $5 with $20 valuation gets 25%).  Make sure you clarify.

todos.title: Early Stage
todos.body: Pay attention to liquidation preference and protective provisions.

todos.title: Later Stages
todos.body: Pay attention to board and voting control.

todos.title: Warrant
todos.body: Option to buy stock at a certain price for a given term.

todos.title: Sharing Ideas
todos.body: Only share your ideas with people you know and would trust.

todos.title: Accredited Investors
todos.body: Only certain individuals can by stock.

todos.title: Convertible Debt
todos.body: Note with interest (6 to 12%) that converts to preferred stock usually when another round is raised.  Can include a discount value (10 to 20%) and a valuation cap to incentivize investor.  Consider a reasonable time horizon with forced conversion and a floor, not a ceiling on conversion value.

todos.title: First Offer
todos.body: Never make the first offer.

todos.title: Ethics
todos.body: Never assume that the other side has the same ethical code as you.

todos.title: Dealing with Family
todos.body: Need to 1.) treat investment as a lottery ticket and 2.) know that holidays are not investor relations meetings.

todos.title: State of Incorporation
todos.body: Most VCs prefer Delaware because corporate law is well defined and business friendly.

todos.title: Liquidation Preference
todos.body: Money returned to a series of stock ahead of other series of stock.  Used on event of mergers, acquisitions, funding, change of control.

todos.title: Competition
todos.body: Make VCs compete by getting multiple term sheets.

todos.title: Employment Agreements
todos.body: Make sure they are negotiated beforehand and included in the deal.

todos.title: Angel Investor
todos.body: Individual investor.

todos.title: Prisoner's Dilemma
todos.body: If two prisoners cooperate, the outcome is best for both of them.

todos.title: Pay to Play
todos.body: If investor does not participate in future fundraising their preferred stock is converted to common stock.

todos.title: Convertible Debt Caution
todos.body: If a company has more debt than assets they are technically insolvent and may have a fiduciary responsibility to debtors, not equity.  Some states impose personal liability on directors for things that occur when insolvent.  In other words, make sure you are following the law.

todos.title: Confidence
todos.body: Have the mindset that you will succeed in your quest of raising funds.

todos.title: Typical Board
todos.body: Five members, founder, CEO, VC, second VC, and outside board member.  Outside board members are usually compensated with stock options.

todos.title: Early Stage Valuation
todos.body: Experience of entrepreneur, amount being raised, perception of overall opportunity.  Current economic climate also plays a big part.

todos.title: Carried Interest
todos.body: Dwarfs VCs management fee.  Profit VCs get after returning money to investors.  VCs also recycle their management fees into their investments.

todos.title: NDAs
todos.body: Don't ask a VC for a non-disclosure agreement.  Guard your secrets but don't be afraid to share ideas with VCs.  They want to protect them like you do.

todos.title: No-Shop Agreement
todos.body: Companies agree not to continue to shop around and to close agreement.

todos.title: Private Placement Memorandum
todos.body: Business plan with legal disclaimers.

todos.title: Negotiating Styles
todos.body: Bully (stay cool), Nice Guy (pressure to close), Detail Guy (don't lose focus on big picture), Wimp (don't be greedy, negotiate for both sides), Curmudgeon (patient, upbeat, tolerant, realize that you'll never please).

todos.title: Conversion
todos.body: Allowing investors to convert preferred stock into common stock to avoid participation amount.

todos.title: Employment Lawyer
todos.body: Add one to your team.  Create an employee management checklist.
